title: Home
text:
Warning



This website is under construction!


Welcome! This website contains the materials for the Light-Sheet Image Analysis Workshop organized by the Light-Sheet Imaging at Universidad Mayor (LiSIUM). The course will be held at the Center for Integrative Biology of Universidad Mayor between 5‚Äì9 January 2026 in Santiago, Chile.


Program Resources



The Light-Sheet Image Analysis Workshop is aimed at scientists at all levels and facility staff who wish to receive training in quantitative image analysis from multidimensional light-sheet microscopy data.





An√≠bal Vargas R√≠os
Luz Mar√≠a Fuentealba
Charlotte Buckley






Marina Cuenca
Agust√≠n Corbat
Bruno Vellutini

title: Original draft program
text:
Caution



Please don‚Äôt edit this page. The current program is here.


Initial draft of the program written by Marina. Keeping it here as a reference.



üß† Morning Session
- Welcome & Course Overview
- Principles of Light-Sheet Microscopy
- Optical setup & acquisition strategies
- Experiment planning and sample mounting
- Common image artifacts and how to avoid/fix them
- Introduction to light-sheet datasets: file types, metadata, scale, volume/time complexity
üñ•Ô∏è Afternoon Workshop
- Multiview reconstruction in Fiji
- Hands-on with 3D visualization in Fiji and Napari



üß† Morning Session
- Fundamentals of BioImage Analysis
- Image types and bit depth
- Noise, background correction, filters
- Thresholding, segmentation basics (pixel vs object)
- ROI handling and masks
- Overview of available open-source tools
üñ•Ô∏è Afternoon Workshop
- Segmentation workflows in Fiji and Napari (2D/3D)
- Intro to cell tracking methods



üß† Morning Session
- Introduction to AI and deep learning in microscopy
- When and why to use DL models
- Overview of StarDist, CellPose
üñ•Ô∏è Afternoon Workshop
- Using BioImage Model Zoo models with Napari
- Hands-on with Labkit and ilastik (interactive annotation & classification)
- Deploying pre-trained models on user data
- Optional: Train your own simple model (time permitting)



üß† Morning Session
- Research applications of BioImage Analysis
- Talks or case studies using light-sheet imaging
- Highlight multi-disciplinary projects (e.g.¬†developmental biology, neuroscience, plant science)
- Tips for designing an effective analysis pipeline
üñ•Ô∏è Afternoon Workshop
- Begin working on personal projects or example datasets
- Q&A with instructors (project clinic)
- Begin structuring project presentations (suggested format below)



üß† Morning Session
- Continue work on projects
- Finalize analysis and prepare presentations
- Instructor support for polishing visuals and conclusions
üñ•Ô∏è Afternoon Session
- Student Presentations (10 min each + 5 min Q&A)
- Suggested format:
1. Dataset and biological question
2. Analysis goal
3. Method and tools used
4. Results
5. Challenges & next steps
- Group Discussion and Feedback
- Closing Remarks & Certificate Distribution
- Group Dinner üéâ

title: Introduction to Thresholding in Fiji
text:
In this exercise we will:

Compare global and local thresholding methods and understand when each is useful.

Improve segmentation using background subtraction and Gaussian smoothing.

Refine masks using binary operations, including Fill Holes and Kill Borders.

Generate labeled objects using MorphoLibJ‚Äôs Connected Components Labeling.

Extract object-level measurements (area, perimeter, circularity, etc.).

Visualize measurement values on labeled images.

Filter segmented objects based on size or other properties.

These steps form a complete workflow:
raw image ‚Üí pre-processing ‚Üí segmentation ‚Üí cleanup ‚Üí labeling ‚Üí measurement ‚Üí filtering
We‚Äôll use MAX_Lund.tif as the example image.




Start Fiji.

Open the image:
File ‚Üí Open‚Ä¶ ‚Üí MAX_Lund.tif


Open the histogram and visualization tools:
Image ‚Üí Adjust ‚Üí Brightness/Contrast‚Ä¶

You should see a histogram like this:



Brightness/Contrast histogram


Idea: Thresholding chooses an intensity value that separates ‚Äúforeground‚Äù from ‚Äúbackground‚Äù. The histogram shows how many pixels exist at each intensity.




Global thresholding applies one single threshold to the whole image.

With MAX_Lund.tif active, run:
Image ‚Üí Adjust ‚Üí Auto Threshold‚Ä¶
Choose:

Method: Try all

White objects


Confirm.

Fiji generates a montage of all global methods:



Global auto threshold montage






Local thresholding requires 8-bit input.

Select the original image:
Window ‚Üí MAX_Lund.tif

Convert to 8-bit:
Image ‚Üí Type ‚Üí 8-bit

Now the image is ready for local methods.




Local thresholding computes a threshold for each local neighborhood.

Run:
Image ‚Üí Adjust ‚Üí Auto Local Threshold‚Ä¶
Choose:

Method: Try all

Radius: 15

Parameter 1: 0

Parameter 2: 0

White objects

Confirm.




Local auto threshold montage






Good segmentation often benefits from reducing background and noise first.



Open MAX_Lund.png.

Subtract background:
Process ‚Üí Subtract Background‚Ä¶

Rolling ball radius: 50


Smooth noise:
Process ‚Üí Filters ‚Üí Gaussian Blur‚Ä¶

Sigma: 1


After preprocessing:



Auto Local Threshold after preprocessing










Run:
Image ‚Üí Adjust ‚Üí Auto Local Threshold‚Ä¶

Method: Otsu

Radius: 15


Local Otsu mask:



Local Otsu mask







Fill holes inside objects:
Process ‚Üí Binary ‚Üí Fill Holes

Slightly shrink objects:
Process ‚Üí Binary ‚Üí Erode

Optionally restore outlines:
Edit ‚Üí Draw

Expand objects after erosion:
Process ‚Üí Binary ‚Üí Dilate

Refined mask:



Refined mask







Remove partial objects touching image borders:
Plugins ‚Üí MorphoLibJ ‚Üí Filtering ‚Üí Kill Borders




Filled + border-removed mask







Convert each connected region into a uniquely labeled object:
Plugins ‚Üí MorphoLibJ ‚Üí Label ‚Üí Connected Components Labeling

Connectivity: 4

Output type: 16-bit

Labeled objects:



Connected components labeling






Quantifying each object is often the main goal after segmentation.
Run measurements:
Plugins ‚Üí MorphoLibJ ‚Üí Analyze ‚Üí Analyze Regions
This extracts a number of morphological associated features. We will select:

Area

Pixel count

Perimeter

Circularity

Ellipse geometry

Bounding box




Morphometry table






Visualize one measurement (e.g.¬†area) mapped onto the label image:
Plugins ‚Üí MorphoLibJ ‚Üí Label Images ‚Üí Assign Measure to Label
Choose Area and apply a colormap.



Area visualization on labels


Useful for:

spotting unusually big/small objects

deciding filtering thresholds

checking measurement correctness





Remove small objects based on size:
Plugins ‚Üí MorphoLibJ ‚Üí Label Images ‚Üí Label Size Filtering

Operation: Lower Than

Size threshold: 100 px




Size filtering



